Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Field-experimental Test for Evolutionary Trait-mediated Indirect Effects in Food Webs
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project utilizes a set of small islands in the northern Caribbean as a model system to understand how interactions between ecological, evolutionary and behavioral factors determine major features of biological communities. The project centers on a large-scale experiment in which presence/absence of large predatory lizards is varied across a series of islands. Large lizards affect smaller, intermediate-size predatory lizards, and the effects cascade down through insect herbivores to the plants. The effects of the top predator on lower trophic levels are mediated largely through effects on the intermediate predator. Such effects can be driven by changes in species densities, but can also depend on specific behavioral and evolutionary traits. The effects of variation in these traits on food-web interactions will be followed over multiple generations. The intermediate predator would be expected to initially decrease but then recover as it behaviorally and evolutionarily adjusts to increased predation risk. The pattern of density change combined with the habitat shift should cause major changes in lower levels of the food web. A comparative study parallels the experiment to determine the food-web pathways generating the experimental results. This study will inform us regarding the interplay between ecology, behavior, and evolution in complex food webs.

This study substantially promotes undergraduate research experiences in field and lab studies and targets groups underrepresented in science. The study also provides graduate-student training and communicates findings to the public via popular articles, public presentations, documentary films, and museum exhibits. Every effort is made to relate this research to applied sciences such as improving agroecosystems, dealing with biological invasions, and preserving species and habitats.

POR.DRECONTENT: This research grant used islands to understand ecological principles, such as how top predators affect the strength and direction of species interactions in food webs, and how such effects can be influenced by intermediate predators via changes in their densities as well as in their evolutionary and behavioral traits. Its main project continued an experiment in which a top predator (a lizard species) was introduced from natural populations on the adjacent mainland to islands having an intermediate predator (another lizard species), with an equal number of unmanipulated islands having the intermediate predator as controls (a third treatment had islands entirely without lizards). The intermediate predator was shown in previous studies to produce many effects on lower levels of the food web, some quite large. How the top predator affects lower levels depends substantially on its effects upon the intermediate predator. Such effects can be on densities, but can also be on behavioral and evolutionary traits; the latter are almost unstudied as to how they affect food-web interactions. The top predatory lizard, which is larger and is primarily terrestrial, caused a drastic habitat shift of the intermediate predatory lizard, forcing it almost entirely off the ground and onto higher and thinner perches. A previous study that measured natural selection on the intermediate predator within one generation found initially selection favored longer-limbed individuals, which are faster on the ground. However, then selection reversed to favor shorter-limbed individuals, which are better able to maneuver on the thin perches of higher vegetation. The present grant examined long term evolutionary changes of the intermediate predator over multiple generations and its effects on other elements of the food web. The expected pattern for density of the intermediate predator was that it would decrease at first but then increase somewhat as the habitat shift selects for individuals better able to feed, survive and reproduce in higher vegetation. There was some indication that population size recovered more than expected over the course of the study, supporting this hypothesis. The pattern of density change, combined with the habitat shift and greater ability of the intermediate predator to feed in the vegetation, was expected to cause the more arboreal arthropods (those in vegetation) to increase at first (because the intermediate predator’s density declines), but then decrease as the intermediate predator becomes better adapted to foraging in vegetation and increases its density there; leaf damage was expected to follow the same pattern. These effects had not yet happened by the end of this reporting period. However,  very strong effects of the intermediate predator on two kinds of spiders (web and ground), expected to be more short-term, did occur and were ameliorated by introduction of the large predator via reduction in the abundance of the intermediate predator.
